material.mattext: The Fundamental Counting Principle states that if one event has m ways and another independent event has n ways, the total number of ways both can occur is m + n.
In permutations, the order of selection matters.
The formula for combinations is C(n, r) = n! / (n - r)!
P(5, 3) means selecting and arranging 3 items from 5 items.
Tree diagrams are most useful for problems with many steps (more than 10).
When choosing pizza toppings, we use permutations because the order of toppings matters.
The number of ways to arrange n distinct objects in a row is n!
If you're selecting a president, vice president, and treasurer from 10 people, you would use combinations.
The Fundamental Counting Principle can be applied when events are dependent on each other.
How many different 3-character passwords can be created using 26 letters (repetition allowed)?
How many ways can you choose 3 students from a class of 10?
A restaurant offers 4 appetizers, 6 main courses, and 3 desserts. How many different 3-course meals are possible?
Which formula represents the number of ways to arrange r items from n distinct items?
How many ways can 5 people stand in a line?
If you flip a coin 3 times, how many possible outcomes are there?
A lock has 3 digits (0-9). How many different codes are possible if digits can repeat?
Which scenario requires using combinations instead of permutations?
Explain the difference between permutations and combinations in your own words.
Calculate P(7, 3) using the multiplication method (not the formula).
How many ways can you create a 2-letter code using letters A, B, C, D if letters cannot be repeated?
When flipping a coin twice, list all possible outcomes in an organized way. How many total outcomes are there?
A computer system has 3 CPU options, 4 RAM options, and 2 storage options. How many different configurations are possible?
You need to select and arrange 3 officers (president, vice president, secretary) from 8 candidates. Is this a permutation or combination problem? Calculate the answer.
List three real-world situations where you would use the Fundamental Counting Principle.
If P(n, 2) = 30, what is the value of n?
A pizza shop offers 8 toppings. How many different 3-topping pizzas can be made? Explain why this is a combination problem.
